unnormalised: New Delhi: In a bid to encourage responsible resource usage, the Delhi Jal Board (DJB) has announced a new initiative based on average household water consumption. As per the latest DJB report released on 20/07/2024, average daily water consumption per household in Delhi stands at 250 liters. Households exceeding this threshold may face a surcharge of 10% on their water bill, starting 01/10/2024.
normalised: New Delhi: In a bid to encourage responsible resource usage, the Delhi Jal Board (D-J-B) has announced a new initiative based on average household water consumption. As per the latest D-J-B report released on twentieth July two thousand and twenty four, average daily water consumption per household in Delhi stands at two hundred and fifty liters. Households exceeding this threshold may face a surcharge of ten percent on their water bill, starting first October two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: The discoms are also pushing for smart meters. Tata Power Delhi Distribution Ltd (TPDDL) reported that average electricity consumption in residential areas rose by 15% in June '24 compared to June '23, with peak demand hitting 7500 MW. They're urging consumers to switch to energy-efficient appliances. A 5-star rated AC can reduce electricity consumption by up to 30%. Consumers can now track their energy consumption patterns via the TPDDL mobile app.
normalised: The discoms are also pushing for smart meters. Tata Power Delhi Distribution Limited (T-P-D-D-L) reported that average electricity consumption in residential areas rose by fifteen percent in June two thousand and twenty four compared to June two thousand and twenty three, with peak demand hitting seven thousand five hundred megawatts. They are urging consumers to switch to energy efficient appliances. A five star rated A-C can reduce electricity consumption by up to thirty percent. Consumers can now track their energy consumption patterns via the T-P-D-D-L mobile app.

unnormalised: The government aims to reduce overall resource consumption by 5% by the end of FY25. Consumers are advised to monitor their monthly utility bills and take necessary steps to conserve water and electricity. DJB offers rebates for rainwater harvesting systems and TPDDL provides incentives for installing solar panels on rooftops. More details on conservation schemes are available at djb.gov.in and tddl.com, respectively.
